text: 、「リプレイ桃子香水 」 The purpose of this meditation is to provide a guided meditation for overcoming compulsiveness. First, is a meditation for maintaining abstinence. Second, is a guided meditation specifically for the eating experience. To work with the act of eating as an opportunity to diminish compulsiveness. It is important to bear in mind that when a person uses the meditative approach to dealing with compulsiveness, that it impacts on all aspects of compulsiveness simultaneously, not just a particular compulsion. In our first meditation to maintain abstinence, we will be focusing on the sensations that come up when we feel the urge to break our abstinence. So this tape can be used particularly at those times for support. Sit down and for a moment feel the body settle and be comfortable in the sitting position. Now, focus in on the sensations within your body. Any sensation that you can detect. The touch of the clothes, the touch of the cushion or the chair, the pumping of the blood, the feeling in the muscles. And any subtle sensations or perhaps gross sensations associated with your mental state. If there are feelings of sadness, deprivation, agitation coming up in the mind, they will also impact within the body. Now begin to explore the sensations within the body associated with the compulsive behavior that you are attempting to abstain from. Notice how if you think about the behavior, sensations will come up. At first, these sensations may be very subtle, tiny hints. You may not even think that the sensation is related to the behavior situation. Start to make an exploration through the body of those sensations associated with your need at this time to indulge, to break the abstinence. You may feel subtle tensions or you may have memories of past indulgences come up and at that time subtle pleasant sensations, body memories of the pleasure of indulging. See if there are sensations in specific locations or whether it's a general sensation over the whole body. At first it may just be the tiniest hint as you feel the urge, the need, as you find yourself making a decision, going through the decision process, should I, shouldn't I. Perhaps very subtle changes in the body sensations. Focus on those. As you focus on them, you will find that they are like the proverbial tip of an iceberg. As you pay more and more attention, they will become more evident. Make an inventory of the entire body. And that many of the most powerful driving sensations are semi-conscious, subconscious, subliminal. They are felt by the deep mind but not ordinarily by the surface mind. As subliminal sensations, they have absolute power and this is why time after time people find that they are driven towards a kind of behavior that they would prefer to avoid based on the surface mind. But the deep mind is influenced by these subtle sensations. Our purpose in this meditation is to make those subtle sensations very evident, to bring them to the surface. Once they have come on the surface, they will be experienced with awareness and equanimity. And once experienced in that way, they will lose their power to drive behavior. And one can achieve an abstinence without effort. The first stage in this process is to detect the tangible body sensations associated with the temptation, the urge to break the abstinence. Continue for a bit more, taking an inventory, exploring. And if no sensations come up that seem to be related, just keep sitting and feeling the body. Remember also that a little bit of thinking covers up a lot of feeling. As much as possible, let go of the thinking process for our purposes here. Just feel the urge in the body. Keep coming back to the body.énd Once you are able to detect some sensation, however faint, associated with the sensation, however faint, associated with your urge or your need to break the abstinence, then you can move on to the next stage of the process. The next stage of the process is to experience that sensation as a physical sensation without associating any psychological meaning, without associating it with any particular ideas or concepts. Just as you would experience the touch of your clothes or a pressure on your body as a mere physical event, try to experience the sensations associated with the compulsion as merely something physical. And in doing that, you will find that you can abide, you can stay with those sensations. They're not really that terrible or intense. In this stage of the process, cultivate an attitude of accepting these sensations and explore them. You can explore them by experiencing them as a single unit or by sweeping back and forth, up and down, sweeping the awareness over the regions, or by focusing on particular locations and holding the awareness there on one spot. Various ways of focusing are possible. The important thing is that every moment that you can spend in a state of relative acceptance of these feelings as body sensation, each moment spent that way means that these sensations are losing some of their driving power. Our job is not to change the sensations themselves, but to change our attitude about the sensations. What gives these sensations power is the attitude of grasping, of locking. Try now to just open up to the sensation without either pushing on it, trying to push it away, and without pulling it towards you, trying to hold on to it. Take a neutral attitude towards the sensation. That neutral attitude withdraws energy from the sensation, withdraws energy from that part of the mind that is associated with the driven behavior. So just experience the sensation with an attitude of non-involvement, hands off, just let it be. Let it come and go, stay or change as it wishes. If the mind wanders, return to the technique. Gently bring yourself back to the actual feelings associated with the need to indulge in the habit. See if you can hang out with those feelings with an even-minded attitude. As much as possible, not wanting the sensations to go, not desiring the sensations stay. Keeping this attitude of relative equanimity is like withdrawing food from a dragon. The dragon may revolt, may start to growl and snap, but as long as one can continue to withdraw food, eventually that monster must weaken. The attitude of non-interference is withdrawing the food. Any interference with the process of feeling, either to push or pull, adds new food. Eventually the compulsion monster will become weaker, but we must understand that before it weakens and eventually dies, it may revolt in a dramatic way. When this happens, bear in mind the principle of consistency. This principle states that all one need do is consistently carry on the practice of observing and accepting the sensations. If this practice leads to a dramatic eruption, just continue to observe that eruption with equanimity. Return to the technique. Letting go of the thinking process for a few more minutes, return to working at the level of pure feeling, the source, the primordial aspect of experience. Work with the feeling body for just a bit longer. Begin now to explore the aspect of sensation called impermanence. Explore the impermanence of the sensations associated with the compulsion or urge. Impermanence means the flowing contour of sensation, as opposed to the qualities of sensation. There is always an aspect to sensation of changing levels, changing locations. Note how the sensation ebbs and flows in some small way. It has a changing contour at all times. The sensation may get a little stronger, a little weaker. There may be pulsations, vibrations. Even when the sensation seems very steady, that very steadiness itself is an aspect of its contour. It's an aspect of stability, just accept that. But if you look on a more microscopic level, the sensation is never completely steady. At some small level, something is always moving and changing. There's some small vibration, some small fluctuation of intensity or outline, configuration or quality. Focus in on that aspect. And in fact, if you are able to detect the aspect of changing contour, you can ignore the sensation itself and just focus in on the qualities of pulsation, movement and vibration. If you are unable to detect these qualities of impermanence, then simply abide, stay with the sensation with acceptance. It is primarily the acceptance which removes the energy from these sensations and eventually allows for an effortless abstinence. But if you are able to detect the aspects of change and impermanence, then this makes the equanimity so much easier. Focus in on the change and impermanence. Experience the sensation as merely energy. And surrender to that energy. Feel it moving and digesting just as the fingers kneading dough soften the dough. So the energy of these sensations will soften the core of your being, breaking up the knots of compulsion. Stay with the awareness of impermanence, pulling away from the thinking process and making contact with the impermanence of the feeling process. And if you cannot detect much movement, pulsation or vibration in these sensations, then stay with the concept of acceptance, equanimity and just be with the sensations. When it comes time to end the session, open the eyes for a few minutes and continue to meditate with the eyes open so as to smooth the transition to meditation in action. Then after a little while, move the body in small ways, maintaining the meditation but not making large movements of the body, again to cushion the transition. And then gradually get up and go about the day's activities. For a moment, sit and let the body become very still. To do this, you can feel the underside of the arms to be a little bit heavy, the underside of the abdomen a little bit heavy. And notice how the body enjoys a state of complete stability. In order to do this meditation, you should prepare some food and have it in front of you. It should be something that you enjoy eating. And we will be exploring the eating process with the viewpoint of both learning to appreciate more fully the pleasant sensations and also from the viewpoint of diminishing the suffering associated with compulsive behavior around eating. Compulsive behavior around eating is either over or under eating. In order to achieve the twin goals of deepening one's sense of satisfaction and diminishing one's sense of suffering, only one technique is needed. Naturally, in addition to the technique that you will be taught here, there are many other possible approaches and techniques. The one you will be taught here is in no way claimed to be the only or the best. However, it is distinctive and it does work. And it has an advantage in that it allows for both an increased appreciation and a diminished suffering simultaneously. Another advantage of the technique that you will be taught here is that it involves only an act of focusing awareness. It leaves the aspect of change of behavior to the process of nature itself. In other words, it sets the stage whereby nature can, in an optimal way, a maximum way, work to free you. Open your eyes for a moment and look at the food in front of you without tasting it. And observe for a moment two things. Observe the types of thoughts that may be arising within the mind. And observe also very carefully the kinds of sensations which may be arising in the body. And observe also the interaction between those two. Without trying to change or manipulate in any way, just be aware what kinds of thoughts are happening, how they're shifting, and what kinds of body sensations are happening. Now, close your eyes and focus exclusively on the sensations within your body. Feel the overall body. Get a sense of whatever is happening there. We will be working with the body sensations. In order to break up the knots associated with the feelings around the eating process, remember that whenever you experience sensations, feelings with an attitude of awareness and acceptance, then the energy within those feelings helps to break up the knots within the deep unconscious mind. Open your eyes now, slowly, and look at the food in front of you, keeping the awareness within the body. See if as you do this, any changes in sensation, perhaps very, very subtle changes, take place. And now, in an exceedingly slow way, move your hand towards the food. And notice any sense of hurriedness, any sense of impatience, any sense of tension associated with moving towards a desirable object very, very slowly. And try to experience that sense of tension or excitement within the body. And if there's no particular sense of tension or hurriedness, just feel the physical body moving, the feeling of the muscles moving. And very slowly, either with the hands or with the eating utensil, take the food up, keeping the awareness within the body. And now, with equal slowness, begin to move towards taking your first bite, understanding that whatever sensations are coming up in the body now, due to this exaggeratedly slow movement, these sensations are always there, hidden, latent, influencing one, whenever one is eating. Our purpose in moving so artificially slowly with this exercise is to bring these sensations to the surface, where we can experience them in a way so as to break up the underlying knots. So with incredible slowness, bring the food towards you, noticing if, as you change the position of the body, as the food gets closer to your lips, any sorts of sensations. Try to let go of the thinking process, just feel the physical body bringing food towards itself, what that feels like in the arms, the chest, the stomach, the back, the legs, the head, the face. And when you have brought the food right to your lips, pause for just a second, continue to feel the body. And now, put the bite of food down, without eating it, and for a moment, just settle into a sitting position, and experience the sensations in the body. Constantly letting go of the analyzing mind, not that there's anything wrong with thought, but for this part of the exercise, we're trying to work at the level of feeling. Stay with the feelings in the body, if any feeling of deprivation has arisen, impatience, focus on that. And if nothing along those lines has arisen, just continue to feel the ordinary sensations in the body, the touch of the clothes, the touch of the chair, the cushion, the pumping of the blood, the feelings in the muscles. Now once again, with the same exaggerated slowness, move the hand towards the food, and experience the physical body moving slowly in the direction of the food. The slower the better. Pulling away from the thinking process, making contact with the feeling process in the body. And when your hand touches the utensil or the food itself, be sure to feel the contact, the actual touch of your hand on that object. And then slowly bring the food towards your mouth. Again, if any sense of anticipation, frustration, hurriedness should arise, welcome that. Feel it in the body. Be glad that it has come to the surface. It is an opportunity to work through the underlying patterns of behavior by experiencing this sensation with awareness and acceptance. And as you bring the food towards your mouth, continue to feel those sensations. And if no special sensation of hurriedness or impatience arises, just feel the muscles of the hand and arm, how they're moving. Feel the rest of the body sitting there, the ordinary sensations. And when the food is just in front of your mouth, pause for just a moment, close your eyes. And in a moment, we are going to switch the focus of our awareness from the body sensation to the taste sensation. The taste sensation arises in the cavity of the mouth, in the nose, over the tongue, and to a certain extent, even down into the throat. Associated with the taste sensation will be other body sensations that you may be able to detect in other parts of the body. They may be pleasant sensations, and they may be very, very subtle. Or they may be unpleasant sensations, tensions. Even as you're experiencing the pleasant taste, there may be tensions in the body, tensions associated with craving or nervousness. Put your awareness within the cavity of the mouth and the tongue. Your primary focus will be in exploring the taste sensations. But also be aware of any other types of body sensations that may be arising in association with the taste in the tongue and the mouth. In a moment, you will take your first bite. When you do, try to be very specific about where the sensations arise. The taste sensations, what part of the mouth, how they spread. Watch the movements of the tongue. Are the tastes on the right side, the left side of the mouth, the upper? Do they extend into the nose? And what parts of the tongue are involved? Front of the tongue, sides of the tongue, back? When you take the bite of your food, there will be a symphony of gustatory sensations that will be distributed throughout the oral cavity. Your job is, with perfect even-mindedness, to observe and be aware as much as possible of the changing patterns of taste sensation without preferences, without aversions. Just feel that part of your body as it is as you taste your food. And as you take now your first bite, do it with the same exaggerated slowness that you used before in reaching for the food. And if you find that this causes unpleasant sensation as well as pleasant, be as open to that. And now take the food and slowly eat it, keeping the primary awareness on the taste sensations. Primary awareness on any other body sensations that may arise. And when you complete your bite, continue to keep awareness within the mouth and tongue. Feel the aftertastes patiently. Also notice if as the pleasant sensation of the taste begins to fade, there might not be some feelings in the body of tension, deprivation, urgency. This is the drivenness to take the next bite. Feeling of the sensation. If something like that arises, if you are able to detect it tangibly, just open up to it. Relieve it by awareness and acceptance. And pause before you reach for the next bite. Pause and just feel. Now once again, reach for the food in the same way as you did before. Very, very slowly experiencing all of the sensations, either just the ordinary physical sensations or the sensations associated with an urge, a hurry. When you touch your utensil or the food itself, be sure to feel that contact, that sensation of touch. And just as you did before, slowly bring the food towards your mouth. Pause for a moment. Focus on the mouth cavity and tongue. And as you take the food, watch the tastes as they move through the mouth and watch any other body sensations. And just as before, as the tastes begin to fade, stay with them for a little while and see if you can detect the urge for the next bite. Don't take the next bite right away. Just pause. See if anything comes up. Understand that there is no such thing as a drive without some kind of sensation associated with it in that moment. What we call a drive or a compulsion or an urge is merely the need to perform some action in order to relieve some subtle pattern of discomfort or in order to magnify some subtle pattern of pleasure. Now it is possible to relieve patterns of discomfort through awareness and openness. And it is possible to magnify patterns of pleasure through the same practice of awareness and openness. So whenever you are feeling an urge, see if you can detect at that very moment what patterns of discomfort are seeking to be relieved or what patterns, memories of pleasant sensations are arising, actually being felt and seeking to be magnified and understand that by the way that you focus awareness on those subtle discomforts and subtle pleasures, you can diminish their power to drive the behavior. So in between each bite, as you continue to eat now, focus in and see if there are any states or pleasures associated with the drive for the next bite. In order to do this, it will be necessary to let go of the thinking process and focus exclusively on the feeling process. And in order to be specific about the feeling process, it is very helpful to locate the feelings as patterns of sensation in the body. And continue to do this until you have eaten all of the food. Okay? See if whenever the sensations of taste arise in different parts of the organism, the sensation of the oral cavity. At the same time, tingling or pleasant sensations in a very subtle level may arise over the whole body. This is the body enjoying the food. Experience those sensations with an open attitude. That means without grasping them, just let them pass through. These are the pleasant sensations that could turn into grasping, into compulsiveness. And also see as you pause between bites if there are any subtle unpleasant sensations. Just open up to them. These are the sensations that likewise can turn into the drive of compulsiveness. And continue to work in this way, understanding that by approaching this particular eating experience in this way, you are training away the habits of unwholesome behavior around food and indeed in the broader sense, you are training away the habits of push and pull in all aspects of your life.
